From: rob <rob@...>

Hi Pete,
Thanks for the advice. I've updated my library sources from GitHub. As I 
use the library in C++ I am currently implementing a few trait 
constructors to dovetail the changes into my system, trying to retain 
the design styles of the original NEAT system.

On a more general NEAT theme, it seems to me that, not using backprop, 
normalisation of input data is far less significant. Is that a valid 
assumption? If it is, then my domain  model is very much simplified as 
some inputs are derived from model feedback and hence vary on previous 
network outputs. This feedback is very variable and most definitely 
non-stationery.

Obviously, some preconditioning of data is necessary to avoid saturation 
of sigmoids etc. So, following on from the above, would it seem 
reasonable to use neuron level trainable traits, on inputs to do the 
necessary adjustments?

Rob

On 19/07/2017 14:55, Peter Chervenski spookey@... [neat] wrote:
> the latest version of MultiNEAT allows the genomes to have evolvable 
> traits independent of the node/link graph. Check out the GitHub 
> repository. The TestTraits.py file in contains the example code that 
> shows how to use the functionality (alongside evolving arbitrary 
> traits for nodes and links).
>
> Peter
